Award.AwardTitle: Advancing Undergraduate to Geo-environmental Master's for Engaged Needs-based Talented Students (AUGMENTS) scholarships program

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The University of Texas at Arlington (UT Arlington) is offering 22 S-STEM scholarships to academically talented and financial-needy students who enter the AUGMENTS (Advancing Undergraduate to Geoenvironmental Masters for Engaged Needs-based Talented Students) program. AUGMENTS is accepting undergraduate students from geology, environmental science, and related disciplines, then shepherding them through their baccalaureate degrees into the Masters degree graduate program in Earth and Environmental Sciences at UT Arlington. The program is recruiting students from UT Arlington and partnering programs at UT Brownsville and UT Pan American. An integrated network of academic and professional support that includes multi-layered mentoring and performance tracking are contributing to the goals of AUGMENTS and are helping to ensure retention and progression to degree completion. A defining element of the program is having the students participate in a "summer learning experience" before their senior year, through which AUGMENTS is aiming to infuse excitement about learning with a hands-on, real world, geosciences research experiences. The summer learning experience is also aiming to instill the skills and confidence students need to master the work of geosciences professionals. The goals of the AUGMENTS program are improving educational opportunities for underrepresented students with financial needs by enabling them to complete undergraduate studies successfully and to earn masters degrees in earth and environmental science. With the growth of the green economy, AUGMENTS is providing students with the relevant experiences and technical skills that employers in this sector expect and need from the next generation of STEM graduates.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The “Advancing Undergraduate to Geo-environmental Master's for Engaged Needs-based Talented Students” (AUGMENTS) scholarship program, was designed to provide scholarships support for senior undergraduates to facilitate baccalaureate graduation and further support the graduates to master’s graduation. Sponsored by the National Science Foundation (NSF), the program addresses a national need to graduate qualified individuals who will either find professional employment in the STEM workforce, or continue on to pursue Doctoral degrees.

 

The Earth and Environmental Science (EES) Department at the University of Texas at Arlington (UTA), in collaboration with the Geoscience departments at the University of Texas at Brownsville (UTB) and the University of Texas Pan American (UTPA), which are located in the Texas Rio Grande Valley (subsequently merged into the University of Texas Rio Grande Valley) recruited two cohorts of 11 students in 2012 and 2013. The program’s goal was to expedite the successful completion of baccalaureate degrees (at each institution) and master’s degrees in earth and environmental science (at UTA) by providing mentoring, professional development opportunities and S-STEM scholarships.

 

The AUGMENTS Program’s objectives included: (1) Providing students with an opportunity to experience an environmental science field camp. Modelled on the EES department’s geology field camp conducted in rural New Mexico, it would be held in the summer prior to the student’s senior year and would involve students participating in field-based study for five-weeks. Each student would gain six credit hours that would be applied to both their undergraduate and graduate degrees. Field camp tuition, fees, and expenses were, as an institutional contribution by UTA, underwritten by the UTA College of Science. (2) Providing students with mentoring at various levels. The students would benefit from having near-peer, faculty, and career mentoring during their time at UTA, the latter drawing on professionals from local government and non-government entities. (3) Provi students with a variety of training and professional development opportunities. Students would be matched with the appropriate professional contacts according to their specific academic and professional interests. Students having a geoscience science focus who might be considering a career path in the oil and gas industry, would be matched with contacts in the energy sector, while those having an environmental science focus would be matched with professional contacts through the EES Advisory Council whose members are drawn from various consulting and governmental sectors.

 

Changes to the original project plan were necessitated by attrition to the recruitment groups. The most significant unanticipated complication resulted from the requirement for relocation to UTA for graduate study. Students from UTB and UTPA, when recruited, understood that once they had obtained their baccalaureate degree, their course of graduate study would be at UTA. Nevertheless, because of what appeared to be a reluctance to relocate, not all of the students were willing to start a master’s degree at UTA. UTB and UTPA are over 500 miles from UTA, and potentially there may have been a perceived difference between sociocultural milieus of the Rio Grande Valley and the Dallas-Fort Worth Metroplex. The loss of students did, however, provide an opportunity to recruit additional students that would be supported for the duration of their graduate studies.

 

The AUGMENTS program was highly successful. During the recruitment periods 26 students were accepted to the program. This total exceeded the originally projected target (22) because additional students were accepted to the second cohort to compensate for attrition in the first. Of those accepted, 23 students successfully obtained passing grades at field camp, while 22 went on to their senior year, with 21 of them subsequently graduating with baccalaureate degrees. The transition to graduate study was made by 15 students, who were joined by three additional

graduate student recruits. Of the 18 students who embarked upon graduate study, a total of 15 have been awarded master’s degrees.

 

The program was tightly structured and required the students to follow an exacting timeline in order to reach a number of important milestones. Those students who accepted AUGMENTS scholarships and completed the program, participated for period of two and a half to three years; a major commitment. This was matched by commitments to program success by program administrators at the NSF, UTA, the partnering institutions, and the project personnel. Given the duration of the student’s participation, it was significant that the number of students graduating with a master’s degree was almost 70% to goal, affirming the programs efforts at retention.

 

Additional student accomplishments included: being the recipients of a variety of local, regional, and national awards and supplemental scholarships, giving presentations at various scientific conferences, and winning internships with governmental agencies and corporations in the field of earth and environmental science. On completion of their courses of study, the students transitioned to the STEM workforce or continued to PhD research.
